title: EP 300 Daniel Rodriguez on AI-Assisted Software Development

rawLines.text: Howdy, this is Jim Rut and this is the
Jim Rut
[Music]
show. Listeners have asked us to provide
pointers to some of the resources we
talk about on the show. We now have
links to books and articles referenced
in recent podcasts that are available on
our website. We also offer full
transcripts. Go to
jimrutshow.com. That's jimrutshow.com.
Today's guest is Daniel Rodriguez.
Daniel's a chief architect, software
architect that is not a building
architect at R potential. Prior to that,
he was an engineering manager at
Anaconda, the Python data sciences
company. And he was a software engineer
at Microsoft. Before that, he had a
varied history of creating online
technology and stuff. So, he's been
doing software for a while. Welcome,
Daniel. Hello Jim. Hey, good to chat
with you again. Daniel and I talk quite
regularly about all kinds of crazy stuff
and uh one of the topics we talk about
is AI software development using these
transformer-based LLM based technologies
and suites of technologies and related
technologies to write software. And uh
this is really something that I'm
passionate about. I've been fooling with
it since almost a week after chat GPT
came out. And I've even done a couple of
goodsized projects. In fact, the most
recent one, Untouched by Human Hands. I
haven't even looked at line of code.
It's quite amazing. Right. Recently, I
had Adam Lavine on the show, Jim Rut
show, episode 289 where we talked about
AI aided software development for non-
techies. Adam is basically a journalist
and thinker and and such, but man, he's
been writing getting creating some
amazing software even though what the
hell he's doing, right? It's amazing.
Daniel, on the other hand, is the other
extreme. Very thoughtful, very
professional, very experienced software
engineer who has been thinking hard
about how to introduce large language
modelbased code generation into a
professional environment. So, that's
what we're going to talk about. Welcome,
Daniel. These days people are talking
about Vive coders and it makes me think
that the Vive coders have been have
always been the professionals without a
PhD in the in the industry like me just
like hacking things around until we get
like professional enough that that we
get you know report and are able to you
know work in in so many different

engineers in the industry is that you
know from the beginning of of software
engineering there has been this debate
of whether software engineering belongs
to the hard sciences or or the soft
sciences. What did you believe? I've
always believed it was mostly soft
science uh mostly the science of
management human factors
etc. But there's a tiny bit basically in
things like compiler design, parse tree,
writing, you know, optimization of
database internals, which used to be one
of my fields that could be called, if
not science, at least hard engineering.
Yeah, those hard parts they uh resemble
so much to the math that it's almost
mimicking the math directly. But but
yeah, I agree with you like the software
in itself is a it's an exercise of
language a culture that you know is so

to the soft sciences quote unquote and
especially these days right we are
seeing that wall be broken down and
people be able to talk more in
programming language. Yeah, you
mentioned vibe programming. It I must

stuff, there's all kinds of ways you can

programming, I think of using one of
these crazed agents where you just type

just to see what will happen. And it
reminds me of like a fairly talented
15-year-old programmer with 6 months of

instead of one. It just goes
errors go flying out. It fixes the

it's hilarious sometime. It usually
actually works for something small like
a 300line website or a couple of
functions or something. But I just hate

writing and engineering a normal
solution, but I just let the AI write

know more or less what the UI looks
like.
We'll say the LLMs are much better at
fonts and colors and shapes of boxes and

has no aesthetic skills whatsoever. So
anyway, I'll turn my rant off about vibe
programming. I mean, people have to

everywhere else. It it just feels that
given that software engineering is such

And it's just that I mean I believe it's
just that the complexity and the energy
that that it takes to ramp up. It was so

that's that's broken. So like if people

there's like a a wide gap and there's

as we all know if you're going to be

And most people I talk to who are smart

Yep. Sounds good. So I was working in

that wave strike back into the company
and uh change begin to change the

Anaconda where the first project I

having that entrance point. So a medium
people where they are in this case
Jupyter notebooks was essential and did

level we were beginning to adopt at
least c culturally within uh my my team
and my surroundings were we were
beginning to adopt AI and generative AI

to the feedback from people it really
helped me understand that I mean if
they're finding it valuable then why not
why can't I find it valuable and then if
I embrace it what does this what does
this mean? So the very next step was to
realize that okay people are using it
but that doesn't mean it's working for

not. At the time models were fairly

opening all this vast set of
possibilities where I am the lead in the

it's almost like a like almost like a

see there are things the AI sees when
you don't and you can leverage the AI to
to move faster certain directions you
just are not seeing at that time and
that really at that moment it really
convinced me to fully embrace it and
ever since then I had just use it for
everything. When was that? When would
you say approximately the first time you
used AI to work on production code? The
first time use AI to work on production
code Q1 last year 2024. 2024. So you
were a late adopter. I was doing it
about the same time in 2023. What were
the first things you actually used it
on? Unit tests. Actually, this is a
central topic to the whole point of
evol. So, a unit test is at a basic
level a confirmation that your biases in
programming are followed through to the
end. So, when you write a function that
you're expecting it should behave in a
certain way, you you would write the
test to make sure it keeps behaving that

change it. What the unit tests do is
that they describe almost a signature of
your system. So in programming languages
that are not as strict as pure
functional programming languages, unit
test become almost the the signature or
the mathematical representation of your
program. So in some environments like
for example in JavaScript there is there
there's a whole community around fantasy
land which they try to bring strictness
to JavaScript and safety in the sense of
type safety to JavaScript and they have
unit tests where they test all the
ranges of action of all the inputs and
outputs of the function. That's why I
meant it similar to the signature of the
program. Let's talk a little bit about
the social side, which is, at least in
my experience, trying to get programmers
to write enough unit tests is really
hard, right? They'd rather be writing
code than writing unit tests. It feels
like extra work. I had a challenge with
that that at the beginning. I I I
thought like in my very early years of

mainly in JavaScript and Python and like
maybe a little bit of Java for school or

when I can do all of these things so

any extra libraries. And just by

working in this isolated fashion where

Well, yeah. So I have embraced it for a

well, I can write my code based on test.
So then you can do test development much

like it cannot be perfect because it it

I well because we know there's they

I bet the the load algorithm prioritized
like say high star GitHub projects

what humans find readable is
